#Text=Juan de Cartagena
#Text=Juan de Cartagena ( died c. 1520 ) was a Spanish accountant and captain of one of the five ships led by Ferdinand Magellan in his expedition of the first circumnavigation of the earth .
#Text=Cartagena frequently argued with Magellan during the voyage and questioned his authority .

#Text=Following a failed mutiny attempt of which Cartagena was the principal organizer , Magellan marooned Cartagena on a remote island in Patagonia in 1520 , before continuing on to the Strait of Magellan .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Cartagena was a native of Burgos , the historic capital of Old Castile . [ 1 ]
#Text=Cartagena was a confidante and " nephew " of archbishop Juan Rodríguez de Fonseca , the influential head of the Casa de Contratación which regulated trade with Spain ’s American colonies .

column1: #Text=Historians have interpreted " nephew " as a euphemism indicating that Cartagena was Fonseca 's illegitimate son . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=His age at the time of Magellan 's expedition is unknown , but he was married and had a daughter , Doña Catalina . [ 1 ]
#Text=Magellan 's voyage
#Text=Trained as an accountant , Cartagena had no experience as a seaman . [ 2 ]

#Text=Despite this , he used his influence with Fonseca to secure appointment as Inspector General ( Veedor General ) of Magellan 's Armada de Molucca with authority to supervise the expedition 's financial and trading operations . [ 4 ]
#Text=King Charles V of Spain also directed Cartagena to report on the expedition directly , rather than through Magellan as captain-general .
#Text=This split responsibility would be a source of difficulty during the subsequent voyage . [ 5 ] [ 2 ]

#Text=In recognition of Cartagena 's influence , and in order to please his supporters , Magellan named him captain of the largest ship of the expedition , the San Antonio , subject only to Magellan 's own authority as captain-general of the fleet . [ 6 ]
#Text=Cartagena earned a salary of 110,000 maravedí , the highest of anyone in the fleet , including Magellan . [ 7 ]
#Text=Tensions surfaced between Cartagena and Magellan as soon as the fleet departed Spain .
#Text=In councils between captains , Cartagena routinely opposed Magellan 's navigation decisions and refused to salute his superior when required by custom to do so .
#Text=A storm delayed the fleet south of Tenerife , and food had to be rationed ; Cartagena took this opportunity to publicly criticise Magellan and suggest he was not competent to command .
#Text=Magellan promptly had him arrested , relieved of his command and confined aboard the Victoria for the remainder of the voyage to South America . [ 8 ]
#Text=Mutiny
#Text=Cartagena remained a captive until the fleet reached Patagonia .
#Text=On 1 April 1520 he secretly left the Victoria and reboarded the San Antonio , where he rallied supporters among the Spanish crew and officers in opposition to the Portuguese Magellan .

#Text=In company with Concepción 's captain Gaspar de Quesada , pilot Juan Sebastián Elcano and thirty Spanish crew members , Cartagena seized control of San Antonio and declared the vessel independent of Magellan 's command .

#Text=The officers of both Concepción and Victoria joined in the mutiny , and on 2 April 1520 a letter was sent to Magellan 's flagship , the Trinidad demanding that the captain-general acknowledge that the fleet was no longer under his command .
#Text=Magellan brought the Trinidad , alongside Victoria and lowered a boat to carry back his reply .
#Text=When the boat crew reached Victoria 's deck they made a pretense of handing over a letter ; when Victoria 's captain sought to take it the boat crew stabbed him to death .
#Text=Simultaneously , fifteen men from Magellan 's ship climbed aboard and attacked the mutineers .
#Text=Victoria 's crew joined their cause and the ship was seized . [ 9 ]
#Text=Cartagena had relocated to Concepción prior to the battle , and so remained temporarily free .
#Text=However , only that vessel and San Antonio remained in the mutineer 's hands .
#Text=Magellan ranged his three ships across the mouth of the bay in which the fleet had anchored , and cleared the decks for engagement with Cartagena 's two vessels .
#Text=In strong winds overnight on April 2 , San Antonio dragged its anchor and drifted helplessly toward Trinidad .
#Text=Magellan ordered a broadside fired , at which the crew of San Antonio surrendered and allowed the vessel to be retaken .
#Text=Realising the mutiny had failed , on April 3 Cartagena followed suit and surrendered Concepción without resistance . [ 10 ]
#Text=Death
#Text=After the mutiny , Magellan held a trial of the conspirators .
#Text=Cartagena 's ally Gaspar de Quesada ( captain of the Concepción ) was sentenced to death by beheading .

#Text=However , Magellan was reluctant to execute a close relative of Fonseca , [ 11 ] so Cartagena was sentenced to be marooned along with another conspirator , the priest Pedro Sánchez de la Reina .
#Text=The sentence was carried out on August 11 , 1520 , four months after the mutiny , shortly before the fleet departed their winter quarters at St. Julian . [ 12 ] [ 13 ]
#Text=Cartagena and the priest were given a small supply of ship 's biscuits and drinking water and left on a small island off the Patagonian coast .
#Text=Neither was seen or heard from again . [ 10 ]
